On Thu, 2004-07-15 at 19:42, stack wrote:
> 
> We haven't done any study comparing the two.
> 
> Interesting is that there is nothing said about compression in the arc 
> format specification. 
> 
> Slinging arcs usually means compressed arcs, at least hereabouts at the 
> archive, so makes sense for us to both write and read compressed 
> versions. I just added a note to the developer manual that talks of the 
> particular way in which gzip; A gzip member per arc record rather than 
> one gzip member to hold the total arc.

That would be nice.

> Its possible to disable heritrix's writing of compressed arcs via 
> configuration, if its local policy to collect in uncompressed mode.
> 
> On "in-format compression ... confuse people", I'm with the Tom Emerson 
> comment that its not zlib thats at fault.

I'm not saying that zlib is any worse or better than other compression
algorithms in comprehensibility.  It's that if you just get the file,
it's binary junk, not the immediately comprehensible ASCII-based ARC
format that had me convinced would be readable 100 years from now.

One could argue that the same holds for hardware or file system
compression, but I would say that in those cases, if you can read the
files, you get it out of compressed mode.  Only if a tape/disk was found
so long from now that none of the original hardware is available and
some kind of other scan is set up would the compression be a problem.

One way to make compression a little more workable would be to not
compress the meatdata lines.  That way, there wouldn't be any confusion
about the length of the block, and it would be possible to understand
the structure of the file without using zlib.  It could (and should) be
indicated in the header what compression style is used.  

-Lars
